instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
threads.message:
5V and 0.035A from charger (96W genuine charger)

There is no liquid damage on the board.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on F7000 got 0.350V (0.030V in diode mode so it is too low).
Removed F7000 and F7001 and on pad 1 of F70001/1 got 1.3V (it is low because it got only 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>?) and 0.515V in diode mode).
On pad 2 of F70001/1 got still 0.030V in diode mode).

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
threads.message:
Check if you get 0.030 reading on any big coil too.
Don't forget L9080/580.
Just in case, check diode mode at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> too.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> can generate 12.3V at <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> even with just 5V input.
It works in buck, or boost coneverter, as needed.

Do you have the same behavior on all USB-C ports?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
threads.message:
Big coils 0.001V in diode mode and 2.4Ohm resistance to ground.
L9080 0.03V in diode mode.
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 0.401V in diode mode - checked on <RESISTOR>R6935</RESISTOR>.

Same behaviour on all ports.

Noticed a solder ball on the edge <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> and <DIODE>D3301</DIODE>.
LDOs on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> shows correct readings in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
threads.message:
"L9080 0.03V in diode mode."
Remove <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> and check again diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
For such low values, better to switch to ohm scale.
SSD is probably dead now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
threads.message:
So the short remains at L9080.
Dead SSD; at least one NAND is burnt.

0.111 is still low reading for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Let the board cools down and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.35V and 5V 0.035A from charger
threads.message:
Board was cool.
Thank you very much for all those details - that will help a lot in the future tests and repairs :)
